Speaker.hpid: Mr. J. Walsh Mr. J. Walsh
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Agriculture the plans, if any, he has, for the development of the pig processing industry in the Cork region; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Agriculture (Mr. Deasy) Austin Deasy
Speaker.P: The main problem affecting the Irish pig-meat industry at manufacturing level is the need for rationalisation of slaughtering capacity and modernisation of processing facilities. Generous grant aid from the IDA and FEOGA is available to suitable applicants for this purpose. Investment decisions themselves are, however, a matter for the promoters who will, of course, be influenced by the prospective viability of planned investment. In so far as Cork is concerned, there is an already substantial involvement in the pigmeat industry in that region and it is expected that this will continue to be the case.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Kitt Mr. Kitt
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Agriculture when a fertilizer grant will be paid to a person (details supplied) in County Galway.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Agriculture (Mr. Deasy) Austin Deasy
Speaker.P: The grant will be paid at an early date.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. H. Byrne Mr. H. Byrne
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Agriculture if he is aware that a person (details supplied) in County Carlow was paid 50 per cent market value of reactor cattle when he recently disposed of thirty head; if he will have the matter investigated with the view of paying full compensation; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Agriculture (Mr. Deasy) Austin Deasy
Speaker.P: This person's holding was last restricted due to bovine TB from October 1984 to June 1985. He was paid his full entitlement by way of reactor grants at the time and there is no means of providing further compensation in his case. The price paid for reactors is a matter for negotiation between the herdowner and the slaughtering premises concerned.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Grant Eligibility

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Faulkner Mr. Faulkner
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Agriculture if specifications for the grant-aided farm improvement programme require that only cement which is certified by the National Standard Authority of Ireland be used; and if he will outline the procedures for ensuring that the requirement is enforced.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Agriculture (Mr. Deasy) Austin Deasy
Speaker.P: Specifications issued to farmers with grant approval under the farm improvement programme prescribe that all concrete products used in grant-aided structures under the programme must be manufactured from cement certified under the licensing scheme of the Institute for Industrial Research and Standards.

MainHeading.P: Because of the limited manpower resources available to my Department, it is not possible to visit each individual farmer in the course of construction to ensure that structures meet approved specifications. Grant aid is paid on the basis of the receipt of a signed statement from the applicant that the works have been carried out in accordance with the approved specifications.

Speaker.hpid: Dr. McCarthy Dr. McCarthy
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Agriculture the reason a drainage grant has not yet been paid to a person (details supplied) in County Tipperary; when this will be paid; and the amount which will be paid.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Agriculture (Mr. Deasy) Austin Deasy
Speaker.P: A land improvement scheme was approved under the land project in 1973 but was not carried out at the time. This approval lapsed automatically when the land project was replaced by the farm modernisation scheme (FMS) in 1974.
A recent application from the person named for a grant for land drainage under the FMS was rejected as the applicant's participation in the scheme had terminated.

The FMS has recently been replaced by the farm improvement programme. The person named is advised to contact his local ACOT office with a view to making application for admission to the programme for grant aid for his future investment requirements.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. J. Leonard Mr. J. Leonard
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Agriculture if he is satisfied at the increase in continental sire breeds in suckler cow heards.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Agriculture (Mr. Deasy) Austin Deasy
Speaker.P: It is estimated that continental sire breeds now account for 40 per cent of matings in suckler herds compared to 30 per cent in 1980. A certain balance in beef breed usage has to be achieved in order to exploit the potential of the various markets. However, the actual selection of breed must remain a matter for the individual farmer.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. J. Leonard Mr. J. Leonard
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Agriculture if his attention has been drawn to an article in the media (details supplied) on silage additives; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Agriculture (Mr. Deasy) Austin Deasy
Speaker.P: I have seen the article referred to. Guidelines for the evaluation of silage additives are at present being considered by the EC Commission in conjunction with the member states with a view to bringing them within the scope of the EC Additives Directives.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Cork District Probate Office.

Speaker.hpid: Proinsias De Rossa Proinsias De Rossa
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Justice if he is aware of the long delays in dealing with applications to the district probate office in Cork; the plans, if any, he has to speed up the processing of applications; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mr. Dukes) Alan Dukes
Speaker.P: I am aware that there has been an increase in the time taken to issue grants from the Cork District Probate Office. In the case of personal applications I am informed that the delay is not significant; in other cases the grant normally issues in about 16 weeks. There are, however, arrangements for dealing with cases where serious hardship might be caused by delay.
The increasing delays are attributable to staffing difficulties. I am arranging for the situation to be examined specially to see what can be done to effect an improvement.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. J. Fahey Mr. J. Fahey
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Justice the reason for the delay in the registration of property (details supplied) in County Waterford.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mr. Dukes) Alan Dukes
Speaker.P: I am informed by the Registrar of Titles that an application under section 49 of the Registration of Title Act, 1964, was received in this case in the Land Registry on 24 January 1986. Section 49 applications are usually of a complex legal nature and there is a long delay in dealing with them in the Land Registry at present. However, consideration of this application is virtually completed and it is expected that registration will be effected in the near future. There has been no undue delay.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Hyland Mr. Hyland Mr. O'Dea Mr. O'Dea
Speaker.P: and Mr. Hyland asked the Minister for Justice if, in view of the recent vandalisation of a cemetery in Limerick, he will consider amending section 51 of the Malicious Damage Act, 1861 as amended by section 12 of the Criminal Justice Act, 1951, to increase the maximum penalties for this type of crime.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mr. Dukes) Alan Dukes
Speaker.P: I am informed by the Garda authorities that persons may be charged very shortly in connection with the event referred to in the question. I consider, therefore, that it would be inappropriate for me to respond to the Deputies' inquiry at this stage.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - County Dublin National School.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. S. Brennan Mr. S. Brennan
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education the present position in regard to the provision of additional classrooms to Divine Word national school, Marley Grange, Dublin 16.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mr. Cooney) Minister for Education (Mr. Cooney)
Speaker.P: As I have already indicated in a recent letter to the Deputy, I have authorised the invitation of tenders towards the end of August next for the proposed extension to Divine Word national school, Marley Grange, Dublin 16.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Connolly Mr. Connolly
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education if he will arrange for a remedial teacher to attend at Rhode national school, County Offaly.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mr. Cooney) Minister for Education (Mr. Cooney)
Speaker.P: My Department has no record of an application from the board of management of Rhode national school, County Offaly, for the appointment of a remedial teacher and, accordingly, the question of making such an appointment does not fall to be considered.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - School Caretakers and Secretaries.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Manning Mr. Manning
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education the number of posts of school caretaker and school secretary which have fallen vacant either through death, retirement or resignation in each of the years 1983, 1984 and 1985; and the number of such posts which have been filled.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mr. Cooney) Minister for Education (Mr. Cooney)
Speaker.P: The information is as follows in respect of posts of caretaker in national schools and of clerk-typist in national and secondary schools:

MainHeading.P: In conjunction with the introduction of the social employment scheme, the Government decided in April 1985 to approve the reinstatement of the 29 posts of caretaker and 34 posts of clerk-typist which had fallen vacant since 1983.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Rationalisation of Post-Primary Education.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. J. O'Leary Mr. J. O'Leary
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education his proposals for the rationalisation of post-primary education in the Caherciveeen area in County Kerry having regard to his recent discussions with post-primary teaching and education interests; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mr. Cooney) Minister for Education (Mr. Cooney)
Speaker.P: Development of post-primary education facilities in the Caherciveen-Waterville area will be by way of a single post-primary school incorporating the two secondary schools in Caherciveen, the vocational school in Caherciveen and the vocational school in Waterville. The school will be under the auspices of County Kerry Vocational Education Committee.
My Department is in consultation with the vocational education committee regarding the development of the new school.

Speaker.hpid: Proinsias De Rossa Proinsias De Rossa
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Labour the progress which is being made with the application to AnCO for the establishment of an all-Irish community training workshop for Dublin's northside.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Labour (Mr. Quinn) Ruairí Quinn
Speaker.P: A national committee comprising of AnCO and the Youth Employment Agency has been established to consider applications for sanction to set up community training workshops. Two such workshops have already been set up in the Ballymun-Santry area. A formal application was received at Finglas training centre from the Irish Community Workshop Committee in February 1986. The committee was informed by AnCO in March 1986 that the AnCO 1986 allocation for community training workshops was fully committed and that a national evaluation of community training workshops was at present being undertaken by the AnCO/Youth Employment Agency Committee.

The outcome of the national evaluation is not expected for some months yet. The application from the Irish community workshop committee will be considered in the light of the proposals arising out of the national evaluation.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Allocations to Voluntary Organisations.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. J. O'Leary Mr. J. O'Leary
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Labour the amount of money available in 1986 for the allocation and payment of grants to voluntary organisations including residents' associations to enable them to provide community and recreational centres; and if he will make a statement on the matter indicating his proposals to deal with applications received since January 1986.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Labour (Mr. Quinn) Ruairí Quinn
Speaker.P: As I have indicated in reply to Dáil Question No. 1 of 6 March 1986 a total sum of £1.2 million is available in 1986 under the capital grants scheme to meet existing commitments and for allocation to new projects. The amount available for allocation to new projects cannot be determined precisely at this stage as it depends on the level of expenditure on existing commitments in the present year. A large number of grants approved in 1985 have involved the carry-over of heavy commitments to 1986 and because of this it will be possible to assist only a small number of new projects this year.

As I also indicated previously, the closing date for receipt of completed applications in respect of the 1986 allocation was 31 December 1985 and applications received after that date cannot be considered until the 1987 provision is being allocated.
